results.title: Broome and the Pearl Coast
results.creator_credit: Sorena, AFFC, Rhonda Mabey, John Mabey and Martyn Down
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Broome, in the remote north-west of Australia is famous for its pearling industry. Travelling the breadth of the Pearl Coast, Ted Egan encounters a number of extraordinary people like Yoshinori Maeda who came to Australia as a young man to fish, but decided to stay. The vast panoramic coast and desert of the north-west is explored, including the beautiful splendour of Deepwater Point, 200kms from Broome.

results.title: Bronzed Aussie gods
results.creator_credit: Light Source Films, Michael Murray and Nick Bleszinski
results.brief_description: The Beach is part of Australia’s cultural landscape, the surf lifesavers the guardians of this beautiful, but potentially dangerous terrain. Saving lives is not all these lifesavers do, at the end of every summer the Australian National Surf Lifesaving Titles (affectionately referred to as the “Aussies” by lifesaving aficionados) are held in April on the Gold Coast. Featuring over 6,000 competitors, this prestigious event is the second largest sporting event in number of athletes only to the Olympics. ‘Bronzed Aussie Gods’ follows three groups of men and women in training as lifesavers, performing real life rescues, enjoying their work, and vying for title glory. Interspersed with their plight is a trip down memory lane courtesy of archival footage capturing the changing customs and costumes that celebrate Australia’s unique relationship with the beach. This results in a film which celebrates Australian beach culture and maps the evolution of a strong aspect of Australian identity.

results.title: Bronze boy
results.creator_credit: New Zealand National Film Unit, Geoffrey Scott, David H. Fowler and David Sims
results.brief_description:
Episode number 228 of Series “Parade”.
A step-by-step record of the creation in 1969 of a life-sized statue of “Young Nick”, a cabin boy on Captain Cook’s ship “Endeavour”. The sculptor, Auckland’s Frank Szirmay, speaks about his work.

results.title: Bronze
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Francois Seguillon and Pierre Moretti
results.brief_description: This film presents the conception and execution of a work of art - a monumental bronze work by Montreal sculptor Charles Daudelin, now standing outside the National Arts Centre in Ottawa. Shows the shaping of the model in its styrofoam stage with knife, saw and blowtorch. The film is without words, but with music to evoke the mood. Credits: Photography by Thomas Vamos and Michel Thomas-d’Hoste; edited by Yves Leduc; music by Maurice Blackburn and sound by Claude Delorme.

results.title: Bronski Beat: the first chapter
results.brief_description: Openly gay, the Bronskis became cover darlings of the British music press in 1984 after the U.K. success of their first two singles, “Why” and “Smalltown Boy” (the latter producing one of the best music videos of all time). A synth-pop trio from London, everything that made Bronski Beat interesting, and at times compelling, came primarily from the larynx of Glasgow-born vocalist Jimmy Somerville. This tape is comprised of mainly music videos.

results.title: Bronenosets Potemkin = Battleship Potemkin
results.brief_description:
Made to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the unsuccessful 1905 Revolution, Potemkin initially drew a mixed response in the Soviet Union, condemned by some for its formalism. Its reception abroad ultimately ensured both popular and critical success at home. Nevertheless Potemkin’s influence, if undeniable, has often been overstated. The Odessa Steps sequence’s power to excite rather than move reflects a relatively narrow authoritarian view of art. Eisenstein’s preoccupations with typage in performance and with each change of shot (or succession of changes) in construction had little influence on the development of film narrative. They now seem most relevant to the TV commercial and music clip. Also available on 16mm and VHS.

Credits: Director, Sergei Eisenstein ; photography, Edward Tisse.

results.title: Bronco busters
results.brief_description: Scenes of cowboys at the Calgary Stampede roping and riding wild horses captured from the ranges of Southern Alberta, Canada. The film also shows roping a calf, bull-dogging a steer, riding a bull, and a chuck-wagon race.

results.title: Bromine - Element from the sea
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles, David W. Ridgway and J. Arthur Campbell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Experiments show the great reactivity of bromine with metals and non-metals, giving products readily soluble in water. A procedure is developed for the extraction of bromine from a dilute sodium bromide solution such as sea water.

results.title: Brolga
results.brief_description: The life cycle of the brolga, Australia’s only red crane, also known as the native companion. Flocks gather in the early morning to feed on insects, rodents and herbage. About September the birds pair off for mating, after a strange courting dance, and raise two chicks, which soon learn to follow their parents around. At about four months they are big enough to fly and join the flock. The film includes a number of remarkable sequences, photographed in slow motion, recording brolgas in flight.

results.title: Broken journey: mending dreams
results.brief_description: A powerful and moving documentary about a family in search of itself. After 18 years in Australia, photographer Hanh Tran is making his first journey home to Vietnam. It’s a dream that has finally come true. Amidst the reunion of tears and laughter, an extraordinary family saga emerges. This film is not only a personal picture of Hanh and his family, but it also about life in contemporary Vietnam - a society in transition.
